DraftKings' Founders Write to Users 
DraftKings' 3 co-founders wrote an email to the company's 4.5 million users , Friday, explaining how the company is handling a perceived breach of ethics that occurred when an employee released inside information, then took a lucrative second place in a FanDuel contest the following day. Here's the letter, posted by a recipient on Twitter: Email sent out to @DraftKings customers. pic.twitter.com/bZcAQ9orqw 
— Stephon Johnson (@StephonJohnson8) October 9, 2015 

Daily Fantasy Player Sues DraftKings, FanDuel 
A daily fantasy player in Kentucky has filed a lawsuit against both DraftKings and FanDuel, alleging the two daily fantasy leaders let him risk at least $100 playing their games, without informing him that each was allowing employees to play the other company's games. The two firms' products are so similar that inside information from one company's games could have been used as an unfair advantage in the other company's contests. The lawsuit seeks class-action status on behalf of millions of other daily fantasy participants. Sports Illustrated reports . 
LogMeIn to Buy Virginia-based LastPass For $110M 
LogMeIn said Friday it has reached an agreement to acquire Fairfax, Va.-based LastPass, a single-sing-on and password management service in a deal worth up to $125M. LogMeIn will pay $110M cash to buy what it said is a high-growth business with millions of users, and it will pay another $15M contingent upon certain milestone and retention targets being reached in the two years following the transaction's completion, which is expected to happen in a few weeks. “We believe this transaction instantly gives us a market leading position in password management, while also providing a highly favorable foundation for delivering the next generation of identity and access management solutions to individuals, teams and companies," Michael Simon, LogMeIn’s chairman and CEO, said in a statement. -- Dylan Martin 
HBS Is Opening a Startup Space in New York 
Harvard Business School is opening a "startup studio" in New York. It's hiring a director and has set up a website for what it describes as "a workspace for high potential alumni ventures and a community gathering space for HBS Alumni who are part of the NYC startup ecosystem." More from BostInno . 
New Hotel in Chinatown 
A New York real estate investment firm is proposing a 17-story, 225-room, limited-service hotel at 73-79 Essex St. in Boston's Chinatown, at the corner of Essex and Oxford streets. They'd demolish the building that's there now, which houses a seafood market on the ground floor and the Ho Toy Noodle Company . The Boston Business Journal reports . 
Boston Launches CityScore, a City Data Tracking Initiative 
Boston City Hall plans to start summarizing critical city data gathered daily into one number, called "CityScore." Mayor's Chief of Staff Dan Koh is working with performance analysts to develop an algorithm to synthesize the data, according to a New York Times report , Thursday. The initiative was formally announced last night. 
Two Sex Assault Victims Sue Uber 
Two women who allege they were sexually assaulted by Uber drivers in separate incidents are suing the ride-hailing company, accusing it of neglect and fraud, misleading them by marketing Uber as a safe transportation option. One of the women is from Boston. “By marketing heavily toward young women who have been drinking while claiming that rider safety is its #1 priority, Uber is instead putting these women at risk,” their complaint reads. The Boston Globe reports .
